ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Tarek is a beast. First he teaches you how the immune system works. Then how to harness that to help people. Really interesting subject, and taught by a guy who really loves teaching and loves his students. Do yourself a favor and take this course if you are a biologist, BME, ChemE or anything remotely related to biological or chemical science. Oh and by the way, you're learning from a guy with like 12 nature papers on this topic.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Information that we learned was very interesting. Class was a little disorganized but the workload was very manageable as a BME elective.
Take it. just take it. If they gave Tarek a TA, this would be one of the best courses at Yale. That's the only improvement I could think of, and that's an easy one for Yale to improve.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Tarek doesn't overload you with written work, which is so nice. If you want to learn, you learn. And frankly, you learn a ton. There were some weeks where I was snowed in with other work...not a problem! I just caught up with Immuno readings the next week. The final project is also pretty awesome. He encourages everyone to take it to lab. Huh, novel idea. Let's actually apply our ideas! Makes this course great.
